items.teaser: We show you how to make our favourite quick and easy recipes for Pancake Day.
items.sub_heading: From simple and quick crepes to fruit-filled, fluffy pancakes for the more adventurous, we show you how to make our favourite recipes for Pancake Day - yum.
items.description: We show you how to make our favourite quick and easy recipes for Pancake Day. From traditional crepes, to fluffy american pancakes and a guilt-free buckwheat healthy option, Pancake day has never been so tasty!
items.title: Best pancake recipes
items.meta_title: Best pancake recipes
items.body:
What with it being Pancake Day on February 21st, it’s time to get clued on some delicious pancake recipes. Here, we pick the best pancake recipes around and tell you exactly how to make them. From quick, simple and easy to make crepe recipes, to fluffy American pancakes and even a healthy option for those of you who don't want to over-indulge, your Pancake Day has never been so tasty!

THE CLASSIC PANCAKE:
If you are after the traditional crepe pancake, then this easy and quick recipe will be just perfect.

Ingredients:

110g/4oz plain flour, sifted
pinch of salt
2 eggs
200ml milk mixed with 75ml water
50g butter
Lemon and sugar to serve

The method:

Sift the flour and salt into a mixing bowl, making a well in the middle for the eggs.
Break the eggs into the well and whisk well, gradually adding adding the milk and water mixture until the batter is smooth.
Melt the butter in the microwave and spoon 2 tbsp of it into the batter and whisk. Use the rest of the butter to grease the frying pan.

Get the pan really hot then turn the heat down to medium before pouring in the batter mixture with a ladel.
Tip the pan from side to side to get it thinly and evenly coated with batter.
It should take around half a minute to cook (the bottom should be golden brown), then flip the pancake over with a palette knife. The other side will need a few seconds only, then simply slide it out of the pan onto a plate.

To serve, sprinkle each pancake with freshly squeezed lemon juice and a pinch of caster sugar..

Et, voila! Your perfect crepe pancake!

Tried and tested top tip: If you want to make this light crepe a little bit naughtier, get your favourite chocolate bar and cut it into very thin slices. When the pancake is still in the pan, spread over the top and cook until it melts. Sprinkle with chopped nutes for a little extra crunch.

COSMO'S MIDNIGHT IN PARIS TRIP - OH LA LA!


THE FLUFFY AMERICAN PANCAKE
If you want delicious filling pancakes that are great when loaded with toppings, then this recipe is for you. Stack them high and top them with treats!

Ingredients:

135g plain flour
1tsp baking powder
Pinch of salt
2tbsp caster sugar
130ml milk
1 large egg
2tbsp butter, melted

The method:

Sift the flour, salt, baking powder and caster sugar into a mixing bowl.
In a separate jug, whisk the milk and egg together and then whisk in the melted butter.
Pour this into the flour mixture and then beat with a fork until smooth.

Heat a non-stick frying pan over a medium heat and ladle in small round dollops of mixture (you’ll probably only fit a couple in the pan).
Wait a few minutes and flip over until both sides are golden brown and the pancake has risen to around 1cm thick.
If you want to keep the pancakes hot as you continue to cook the rest of the batter, pop them in a warm oven as you finish.

To serve, spread with a little butter and cover in lashings of maple syrup.

Tried and tested top tip: If you fancy getting fruity, heat a little sugar and butter over a medium heat in a separate pan until it forms a caramel sauce. Cut two bananas in half and fry them in the pan until golden, adding in blueberries to heat in the pan too. Serve on top of the pancakes and drizzle with maple syrup.

COSMO TRIES: GILGAMESH SUPERFOOD MENU


THE GUILT FREE PANCAKEE
If you want to enjoy Pancake Day without ruining you're healthy lifestyle, then these simple pancakes taken from the Trimmer You Bootcamp menu plan will be just what you need.

Ingredients:  

135g buckwheat flour 
1 egg
300ml soy milk
3tbsp water
1tbsp vegetable oil

To garnish:

4 nectarine, sliced
4 tsp Maple Syrup

  The method:  
Sift the flour into a bowl and add the egg 
Slowly add soy milk and mix well 
Add water to achieve consistency  

Heat the oil in a non-stick frying pan over a medium heat 
Pour in mixture to required size, think about 3-4 inches round
Flip and cook until firm 

Serve them stacked high, with the sliced nectarine and a tsp of maple syrup for each  .

Tried and tested top tip: If nectarines aren't your thing you can swap these for any type of fruit. If you're feeling really good, use freshly pureed apple instead of maple syrup to drizzle on top, and sprinkle with a little cinnamon.

FOOD ON THE GO: QUICK AND HEALTHY OFFICE LUNCHES

 

When you're done, tweet us pics of your pancake masterpieces to @CosmopolitanUK

items.teaser: Here's how to make your moment of truth truly mind-blowing
items.sub_heading: Here's how to make your moment of truth truly mind-blowing
items.description: You've read enough about her orgasm, now it's your turn. Here's how to make your moment of truth truly mind-blowing
items.title: How to improve your orgasm
items.meta_title: You've read enough about her orgasm, now it's your turn. Here's how to make your moment of truth truly mind-blowing
items.body:
1. Use your love muscle

Great abs may help you get lucky, but if you want to get the most from the experience you need to work on your pubococcygeal (PC) muscle. At the floor of your pelvis, it controls peeing and spasms during climax, which is why doctors and sex therapists recommend developing it to improve orgasm and reduce the chances of premature ejaculation. It's also the muscle that enables dogs to wag their tails, but that's another story entirely. Kegel exercises will develop PC power. Squeeze the muscle you use to hold back your pee. Once you've identified this muscle, tighten it, hold for two seconds, then release. Repeat 20 times, three times a day, gradually holding it tight for longer. And keep at it. "Kegels must be done on a regular basis to have any benefit," says Gordon Muir, consultant urologist at King's College Hospital.

2. Take it to the edge

No technique is as successful in improving male orgasms as edging – holding back at the point of no return, resting, then working up to it again. And again. And again. Practise by masturbating until you're about to come, then stop, slow your breathing and wait 30 seconds before carrying on. Or try preventing ejaculation by gently pulling down on your testicles or squeezing the tip of your penis just as you're about to orgasm. Then repeat the process. Master the art of edging and you'll achieve contractile or "dry" orgasms: all the fun of the Big "O" minus the ejaculation and subsequent loss of wood. If you practise enough you may even experience the male multiple. "The technique can result in incredibly intense orgasms," says Dr Barbara Keesling, lecturer at California State University, USA.

3. Watch Saturday's big match

Or work out. Or rent The Godfather Part II. Or go for a run. All of these activities have been shown to raise testosterone levels. (By studies at the University of Northumbria, the College of Kinesiology at the University of Saskatchewan, Canada and the University of Michingan, USA, respectively, if anyone asks.) And researchers at Athens' Military Hospital in Greece found that the more testosterone a man has in his bloodstream, the better his chances of achieving orgasm.

4. Don't play with yourself

Okay, stop "practising". Masturbation won't give you the kind of mind-blowing eye-roller that sex will. You know it, your partner knows it and what's more Mother Nature likes it that way. According to a study by Stuart Brody, professor of psychology at the University of Paisley in Scotland, the body releases 400% more of the hormone prolactin (which makes us feel sexually satisfied) following vaginal penetration than it does after masturbation. "Evolutionary forces always reward behaviours associated with successful reproduction," says Brody. "And penile-vaginal sex is the only sexual behaviour that passes on your genes."

items.keywords: healthy pork recipes, pork recipes, herb crusted pork, pork tenderloin, almond recipes
items.promo_title: Roasted Almond and Herb-Crusted Pork Tenderloin
items.sub_heading: There’s something about an herb crust that transforms even the most basic meat into a show-stopping dish. Case in point: this tenderloin, which is ideal for a weeknight meal but has enough gravitas for a special family feast or holiday spread.
items.title: Roasted Almond and Herb-Crusted Pork Tenderloin
items.meta_title: Roasted Almond and Herb-Crusted Pork Tenderloin – Pork Recipes

ingredient.ingredient_old: 1 slice country bread, crust removed and bread torn into 1-in. pieces
ingredient.ingredient_comments: crust removed and bread torn into 1-in. pieces

ingredient.ingredient_old: ¼ cup fresh flat-leaf parsley, roughly chopped

preparation_step.preparation_step: Heat oven to 400°F. Line a rimmed baking sheet with parchment paper or foil. In a food processor, roughly chop the almonds and 2 cloves garlic. Add the bread and parsley and pulse until small crumbs form.

Season the pork with ¼ tsp each salt and pepper, then spread with the mustard. Coat with the bread-crumb mixture, pressing gently to help it adhere. Transfer the pork to the prepared baking sheet and roast until the internal temperature reaches 145°F, 18 to 22 minutes. Let rest at least 5 minutes before slicing.

Meanwhile, thinly slice the remaining 2 cloves garlic. Heat the oil in a large skillet over medium heat. Add the garlic and cook, stirring, until golden brown, about 2 minutes. Add the spinach and ¼ tsp each salt and pepper and cook, tossing, until beginning to wilt, about 2 minutes. Serve with the pork.

body.intro_text: There’s something about an herb crust that transforms even the most basic meat into a show-stopping dish. Case in point: this tenderloin, which is ideal for a weeknight meal but has enough gravitas for a special family feast or holiday spread.
body.tip_text:
For a delicious next-day lunch, layer the sliced pork and spinach on toasted bread and top with some sliced
provolone.

items.keywords: casserole recipes, baked pasta, italian recipes, spinach and artichoke, pasta recipes
items.sub_heading: Ever been to a party where the golden, bubbly spinach-artichoke dip wasn’t the first to go? Didn’t think so. Expect the same when serving this dish, which takes the idea even further by mixing in short pasta.
items.title: Spinach & Artichoke Baked Pasta
items.meta_title: Spinach & Artichoke Baked Pasta – Italian Recipes

ingredient.ingredient_old: 12 oz short pasta, such as orecchiette or mezzi rigatoni
ingredient.ingredient_comments: such as orecchiette or mezzi rigatoni

ingredient.ingredient_old: 4 oz lowfat cream cheese, at room temperature
1 10-oz pkg frozen leaf spinach, thawed and squeezed of excess moisture
ingredient.ingredient_comments: thawed and squeezed of excess moisture

ingredient.ingredient_old: 1 13.5-oz can artichoke hearts, rinsed, squeezed of excess moisture and chopped
ingredient.ingredient_comments: rinsed, squeezed of excess moisture and chopped

preparation_step.preparation_step: Cook the pasta according to package directions. Reserve 1/2 cup of the cooking liquid, then drain the pasta.

Meanwhile, heat the oil in a large skillet over medium heat. Add the onion and 1/2 tsp each salt and pepper and cook, covered, stirring occasionally, until tender, 8 to 10 minutes. Add the garlic and cook, stirring, for 1 minute.
Heat broiler. In a large bowl, combine the sour cream, cream cheese, Parmesan, lemon zest and lemon juice; stir in the onion mixture.
Add the pasta to the bowl and toss to coat. Stir in the spinach, artichokes and 1/4 cup of the cooking liquid (adding more liquid if the pasta seems dry). Fold in 1/2 cup mozzarella.
Transfer the pasta mixture to a broiler-proof 2 1/2- to 3-qt casserole dish. Sprinkle with the remaining 1/2 cup mozzarella and broil until golden brown, 3 to 5 minutes.

body.intro_text: Ever been to a party where the golden, bubbly spinach-artichoke dip wasn’t the first to go? Didn’t think so. Expect the same when serving this dish, which takes the idea even further by mixing in short pasta.
body.tip_text: Make it ahead: Line the casserole dish with foil, leaving a 3-in. overhang on two sides. Fill the dish with the prepared pasta mixture and freeze until just firm, about 20 minutes. Using the overhangs, lift the pasta out of the dish in one piece. Wrap in plastic, then foil, and freeze for up to 2 months. To serve: Let thaw in the refrigerator, remove the foil and plastic, and transfer the pasta to a broiler-proof casserole dish.  Reheat, covered, in a 375°F oven, about 20 minutes. Sprinkle with 1/2 cup mozzarella and broil as directed.

items.keywords: beef recipes, potato pie, casserole recipes, bbq beef
items.title: BBQ Beef & Mashed Potato Pie
items.meta_title: BBQ Beef & Mashed Potato Pie – Beef Recipes

ingredient.ingredient_old: 2 lb Yukon gold or white potatoes, peeled and cut into 2-in. pieces

preparation_step.preparation_step: Place the potatoes in a pot. Add cold water to cover; bring to a boil. Add 1 tsp salt; simmer until just tender, 15 to 18 minutes. Reserve ¼ cup of the cooking liquid; drain the potatoes and return to the pot. Mash with 3 Tbsp oil, ¼ tsp each salt and pepper and 2 Tbsp of the reserved cooking liquid (add more liquid if necessary).

While the potatoes are cooking, heat the remaining Tbsp oil in a large skillet over medium heat. Add the onion and ¼ tsp each salt and pepper and cook, covered, stirring occasionally, until tender, 8 to 10 minutes.

Heat broiler. Add the beef to the onion and cook, breaking it up with a spoon, until no longer pink, 5 to 6 minutes. Spoon off and discard any grease. Add the tomatoes and cook, stirring occasionally, for
4 minutes. In a bowl, whisk together the ketchup, vinegar, mustard, molasses and Worcestershire; add to the beef and cook, stirring, for 1 minute.
Transfer the beef mixture to a 2-qt broiler-proof baking dish and top with the mashed potatoes. Broil until beginning to brown, 2 to 4 minutes.

body.intro_text: Put a deconstructed spin on burger and fries with this homey combination of sweet barbecue beef and mashed potatoes. For extra flavor, spice up the meat mixture with 1 tsp of ancho or chipotle chili powder.

ingredient.ingredient_old: 1 lb peeled and deveined large shrimp
⅓ cup small sweet red cherry peppers (such as Peppadew), quartered
ingredient.ingredient_name: small sweet red cherry peppers (such as Peppadew)

preparation_step.preparation_step:
Cook the linguine according to package directions. Reserve ¼ cup of the cooking liquid; drain the pasta and
return it to the pot.
Meanwhile, heat the oil in a large skillet over medium heat. Add the garlic and cook, stirring, until light golden brown, about 1 minute. Add the wine and bring to a simmer.
Season the shrimp with ¼ tsp each salt and pepper, add to the skillet along with the cherry peppers, and cook, turning the shrimp once, until they are opaque throughout, about 2 minutes per side.
Toss the pasta with the shrimp mixture and arugula (add the reserved cooking liquid, 1 Tbsp at a time, if the pasta seems dry).

body.intro_text: Fast, light and filled with sweet-hot flavor, this heart-healthy pasta gets everything you need for dinner in one bowl: greens, grains and protein in the form of briny, plump shrimp.
body.tip_text: Have leftover sweet red cherry peppers on hand? Make an easy spread for crackers by chopping the sweet, slightly hot peppers and mixing them with cream cheese and chopped parsley. Or fold them into steamed rice, tuna salad or scrambled eggs.

items.teaser: Not everyone loves this superfood - yet.
items.sub_heading: Not everyone loves this superfood - yet.
items.description: Ever wonder how to cook and prepare kale? Try these kale recipes for a blast of Vitamin A, Vitamin K and beta carotene.
items.title: 3 Out-of-the-Box Ways to Make Kale Taste Good
items.meta_title: Kale Recipes - How to Cook with Kale
items.body:
If you're looking for a food that divides the health nuts and the farmers' market crowd from the others, kale is probably it.

It's abundant, cheap and super nutritious but the closest many people get to it is the meat counter at the supermarket, where it's often used as a green base to show off the red cuts of beef.

Before we offer recipes for a kale conversion, let's sing its praises: First, it's a superfood, ranking among the foods with the most Vitamin A, Vitamin K and beta carotene. In many climates, it's an easy-to-grow perennial vegetable, and it's available from the winter farmers' market, given it's tolerance for cold weather.

One word of caution: In the Environmental Working Group's ranking of the dirty dozen foods with the highest pesticide residues, which is based on government testing data, kale and other dark leafy greens have often made the list. So it's a good vegetable to buy organic.

But how do you make it taste good? Some people can drink it raw, in a smoothie, but this article is not for them. Here are a few out-of-the-box ideas that go beyond sauteing or tossing in a salad.

Kale Chips: Simply trim and toss kale greens with olive oil and salt, and bake until crisp for a unique snack, garnish or side dish. One big bunch makes enough kale chipsfor four people to taste, but expect the greens to cook down considerably.

Soups: Kale can be paired with other vegetables, especially potatoes, for a delicious soup. Try peasant-style potato-kale soup or Curly Kale Soup, found in The Big Book of Quick & Healthy Recipes: 365 Delicious & Nutritious Meals in Under 30 Minutes.

Kale-Stuffed Peppers: Chef Louisa Shafia, author of Lucid Food, mixes kale with tempeh, onions and spices for a full-flavored vegetarian stuffed pepper recipe that can even be described "meaty."

Enjoy!

items.title: Slow Cooker Balsamic-Ginger Chicken Lettuce Cups
items.meta_title: Balsamic-Ginger Chicken Lettuce Cups – Chinese Recipes

ingredient.ingredient_old: 1½ lb boneless, skinless chicken thighs, trimmed
1 small head Boston lettuce, leaves separated

preparation_step.preparation_step: In a 5- to 6-qt slow cooker, combine the sugar, vinegar, soy sauce, ginger, garlic and red pepper (if you prefer more spice, use 1/2 tsp here). Add the chicken and turn to coat. Cook, covered, until the chicken is cooked through and very tender, 6 to 7 hours on low or 3 to 4 hours on high.
Twenty-five minutes before serving, cook the rice according to package directions.
Meanwhile, cut away the peel and white pith of the orange. Cut the orange into thin half-moons and place in a medium bowl. Fold in the scallions.
Using two forks, gently shred the chicken into medium pieces and stir into the cooking liquid. Fill the lettuce leaves with the rice and top with the chicken and the orange mixture.

body.intro_text: The slow cooker shouldn’t just be the bastion of rustic stews and brawny meats—you can also use it to create tender, light fare, like this tangy Asian-styled chicken spiced with ginger, garlic and brown sugar.
body.tip_text: The balsamic-ginger sauce is just as tasty with beef or pork. Use flank steak (cut crosswise into 2-in.-thick pieces; shred after cooking) or pork shoulder (trimmed and cut into 2-in. pieces; add 1 hour to the cooking time).

items.teaser: More than 30 new Element hotels are to be built. Here's a look inside the first.
items.sub_heading: More than 30 new Element hotels are to be built. Here's a look inside the first.
items.description: A review of the Element Lexington and the Element hotel chain, Starwood's green hotel chain.
items.title: Hotel Review: The Original Element Hotel
items.meta_title: Element Lexington Hotel Review - Green Hotels
items.body:
There's good news for green consumers on the go, as Starwood Hotel and Resorts has 10 Element hotels open in the U.S., with plans to open dozens more around the world in the coming years, including in Harrison, N.J., and Vaughan, Ontario, in 2013; Vancouver and Frankfurt in 2014; Miami Doral in 2015; and Muscat, Oman, in 2016.

Each of these will, like the original Element Lexington (Massachusetts), be built to LEED green building standards, and cater to customers willing to (possibly) pay a little extra to lessen the impact of their travels while enjoying sleek modern style.

I recently stayed a night with my wife and baby at Element Lexington to see first-hand how this chain catering to the green consumer measures up. The short answer: they don't disappoint.

Built in 2008, Element Lexington is the only Starwood-owned and manager of the bunch; the others are franchises, but operate under the same guidelines to build and operate using non-toxic and local materials, and to operate using technology and practices that reduce both energy and water waste. The packaging is modern and comfortable--from dubbing the lobby a "common space" for communal breakfasts featuring more appealing light and organic yogurt-and-granola-type options than your typical Continental breakfast buffet, to the energy-saving but still gigantic TV offering on-demand movies in the midst of a room designed with a modern color palette and crisply drawn lines.

Like any thoughtfully designed and built green building, you can get dizzy cataloging its attributes, from soy fill in the cushions to faucet aerators to cut water usage by a third. For guests some of the most appealing features include the availability of both recycling and compost bins, the filtered water on tap, the lack of chlorine in the pool (it's a natural salt pool,) and the dishes and flatware in the kitchenette. For drivers of hybrid and electric cars, there are even prime reserved parking spaces.

That's a glimpse of Element Lexington. Each Element hotel is different. The Element Times Square, for instance, offered a farmers market of sorts, so guests could order a cache of Vermont-grown vegetables. (While undoubtedly appealing for some travelers, I personally could not imagine staying in midtown Manhattan and not eating out at every opportunity.)

Here's what is consistent about this hotel chain: You will get the feel of a modern boutique hotel and low-impact green design wrapped in the staffing and quality assurance that comes with staying with one of the world's largest hotel companies.

Therein also lies my one disappointment. There's nothing bad to say about the Element hotel chain. So why isn't Starwood making green design a feature of all it's hotel chains, which also include the Sheraton, St. Regis, Le Méridien, W, Westin, Four Points and Aloft brands? In all, there are 1,076 Starwood-branded hotels, with over 315,000 rooms.

The Element brand is a great option for the green consumer, but we would really celebrate if the Element brand was less a green feather in Starwood's cap than an incubator used to test green practices and designs to be rolled out at its sister brands across the world.

ingredient.ingredient_old: 2 bone-in chicken breast halves (about 2 lb total)
ingredient.ingredient_name: bone-in chicken breast halves (about 2 lb total)

ingredient.ingredient_old: 1 lb sweet potatoes, peeled and cut into ½-in. pieces

preparation_step.preparation_step: Place the chicken, potatoes, celery, onion, tomato paste, cumin and paprika in a large pot. Add the broth, cover and bring to a boil.

Reduce heat, add ¾ tsp salt and  ½ tsp pepper and simmer, covered, until the chicken is cooked through and the vegetables are tender, 15 to 20 minutes. (Skim and discard any foam that rises to the top.)
Transfer the chicken to a bowl. When cool enough to handle, shred the meat, discarding the skin and bones.
Stir the chicken back into the soup along with the chickpea and couscous. Simmer for 3 minutes.

body.intro_text: Tired of the same old chicken soup? Turn to Morocco for inspiration with this lively blend of chunked sweet potato, couscous and chickpeas, all flavored with ground cumin and smoked paprika.
body.tip_text: Make it ahead: You can refrigerate the soup for up to 3 days or freeze for up to 3 months. Thaw in the refrigerator overnight. Reheat in a large saucepan, covered, over medium heat for about 20 minutes.

preparation_step.preparation_step: Place the chicken, carrots, celery and onion in a large pot. Add the broth, cover and bring to a boil.

Reduce heat, add ¾ tsp salt and ½ tsp pepper and simmer, covered, until the chicken is cooked through and the vegetables are tender, 15 to 20 minutes. (Skim and discard any foam that rises to the top.)
Meanwhile, cook the rice according to package directions.
Transfer the chicken to a bowl. When cool enough to handle, shred the meat, discarding the skin and bones. Stir the chicken back into the soup and bring to a gentle simmer.

In a medium bowl, whisk together the eggs and ¼ tsp salt until frothy. Whisk in the lemon juice. Whisking constantly, gradually add 1 cup of the hot chicken soup (liquid only) to the egg mixture. Gradually whisk in an additional cup of soup. Stir in the parsley. Stir the egg-soup mixture and rice into the soup in the pot; warm for 2 minutes (do not let it simmer or boil).

items.title: Cheesy Polenta & Mushroom Pizza
items.meta_title: Cheesy Polenta & Mushroom Pizza – Easy Pizza Recipes

ingredient.ingredient_old: 2 oz Gruyère or Swiss cheese, shredded (½ cup)
8 oz shiitake mushrooms, stems discarded, caps sliced ¼ in. thick

preparation_step.preparation_step: Line a baking sheet with parchment paper. Cook the polenta according to package directions. Remove from heat and stir in the Parmesan, 1/4 cup Gruyère and 1/4 tsp each salt and pepper. Scrape the polenta onto the prepared baking sheet and spread out to form a 3/4-in.-thick oval.

Heat broiler. Heat 2 Tbsp of the oil in a large skillet over medium high heat. Add half the mushrooms and cook, tossing often, until golden brown and just tender, 4 to 5 minutes; transfer to a plate. Cook the remaining mushrooms with the remaining Tbsp oil.
Return the first batch of mushrooms to the skillet and toss with the shallot, thyme, 1/2 tsp salt and 1/4 tsp pepper.
Scatter the mushroom mixture over the polenta and sprinkle with the remaining 1/4 cup Gruyère. Broil until the cheese begins to brown, about 3 minutes. Serve with a salad, if desired.

body.intro_text: Skip traditional dough and liven up pizza night with a more flavorful base for your pie. Polenta makes a delicate and delicious foundation for a mixture of button mushrooms, shiitakes, shallots and Gruyère cheese.
body.tip_text: Use the polenta as a base for other tasty toppings. Try roasted tomatoes, or replace half the mushrooms with cooked sausage and spinach.

ingredient.ingredient_old: 2 lb boneless, skinless chicken breasts, cut into 1-in. pieces

preparation_step.preparation_step: Heat oven to 375 degrees F. Place the chicken in a large pot. Add water to cover; bring to a boil (about 10 minutes). Drain; set aside.

Meanwhile, heat the oil in a large skillet over medium heat. Add the carrots, onion and 1/2 teaspoon salt and cook, covered, stirring occasionally, until tender, 8 to 10 minutes. Stir in the Cajun seasoning.

Sprinkle the flour over the vegetables; cook, stirring, for 1 minute. Gradually stir in the orange juice, then the broth; bring to a boil. Add the chicken, peas, dill, and half the parsley and stir to combine. Remove from heat and stir in the buttermilk.

Transfer the mixture to a 2 1/2- to 3-quart baking dish and bake for 15 minutes. In a medium bowl, combine the cornflakes and the remaining parsley. Sprinkle over the chicken mixture and bake 5 minutes more. Let stand for 10 minutes before serving.

body.intro_text: Could it get any better than the flavor combination of chicken pot pie and buttermilk fried chicken? Actually, yes — when that creamy and comforting mix is a mere 258 calories and 7 grams of fat per serving.
body.tip_text: Make it ahead: Prepare the chicken mixture and refrigerate for up to 2 days. When ready to cook, transfer the mixture to a casserole dish and reheat, covered, in a 375 degrees F oven for 20 minutes. Top with the cornflakes and continue to bake as directed.

4 oz sharp Cheddar cheese, shredded (about 1 cup)

preparation_step.preparation_step: Heat oven to 350°F. Oil a 2½- to 3-qt baking dish. In a large bowl, whisk together the eggs, milk, mustard, nutmeg and ¼ tsp each salt and pepper. Add the bread and let sit, tossing occasionally, for 5 minutes.

Fold the onion, apple, ham and cheese into the bread mixture. Transfer to the prepared baking dish. Bake until set and a knife inserted in the center comes out clean (cover the bread pudding with foil if it browns too quickly), 45 to 50 minutes. Serve with salad, if desired.

body.intro_text: Bread pudding isn’t just for dessert, and good thing—this rustic yet rich-tasting combination of apples, ham and cheese makes for a delicious (and super-simple) addition to brunch or lunch.

preparation_step.preparation_step: Form the beef into twelve 1/2-in.-thick patties and season with the cumin, oregano, and 1/2 tsp each salt and pepper.

Heat 1 tsp oil in a large skillet over medium heat. Cook half the patties to the desired doneness, 3 minutes per side for medium; transfer to a plate. Cook the remaining patties. Return the first batch of burgers to the skillet and add the lemon juice; turn the burgers to coat.
Meanwhile, in a medium bowl, combine the cucumber, onion, mint, remaining Tbsp oil, and 1/4 tsp each salt and pepper.
Spread the flatbread with the yogurt and top with the burgers and cucumber relish.

Layer it in a pita pocket or on crisp baguette, or try using ground lamb instead of beef and adding crumbled feta to the cucumber relish.

items.promo_teaser: The human body has evolved to stockpile fat. Here's how you can beat the system at every stage
items.keywords: shed pounds, process fat, fat, lose fat, lose weight

related_links_list.link_text: MH investigates: Obesity in the UK
10 dinner recipes that will help you lose weight

items.teaser: The human body has evolved to stockpile fat. Here's how you can beat the system at every stage
items.sub_heading: The human body has evolved to stockpile fat. Here's how you can beat the system at every stage
items.description: The human body has evolved to stockpile fat. Here's how you can beat the system at every stage
items.title: How to short circuit fat storage
items.meta_title: The human body has evolved to stockpile fat. Here's how you can beat the system at every stage
items.body:
1. Chew it up

"All fat stored in your body comes from food," says David McCarthy, professor of nutrition and health at London Metropolitan University. Good digestion helps you process fat, and this starts with saliva, so work on your mastication.

Fight it Add lemon juice to water, tea, yoghurt and salads. It triggers saliva production and helps break down lipids.

2. Gut reaction

When full, your stomach empties into the first part of the small intestine, called the duodenum. “Here bile is released, making fat easier to absorb,” says McCarthy.

Fight it Add vinegar to fatty foods. Research in The Journal of Agriculture and Food Chemistry found that vinegar increases the production of stomach acids, reducing your body’s fat storage by up to 10%.

3. Fat transformation

“Your pancreas releases the enzymes that break down fat,” says McCarthy. It’s then converted into fat globules called chylomicrons which are transported in your bloodstream.

Fight it Gorge on blueberries. Studies have demonstrated that this potent fruit can reduce chylomicrons by 73%.

4. In the blood

“Chylomicrons circulate in the blood until they are taken up by fat-storing cells called adipose tissue," says McCarthy.

Fight it Switch from white to brown sugar. The molasses in brown sugar are high in polyphenols, which reduce this tissue.

5. The soft cell

The adipose tissue is broken down by enzymes into fatty acids, which are then taken up by the fat cells.

Fight it Lower your carb intake to 43% of your daily calorie allowance. Research by The Endocrine Society found this can reduce fat levels by 11%.

 

Words: Wesley Doyle. Illustration: Spooky Pooka at Debut Art
Follow MH on Twitter and Facebook

items.promo_teaser: Train your self-control like a muscle and you'll boost your ability to resist temptation
items.keywords: temptation, motivation, beat your vices, willpower, vices
items.teaser: Train your self-control like a muscle and you'll boost your ability to resist temptation
items.sub_heading: Losing your gut is as much about strength of mind as it is about diet and working out. Train your self-control like a muscle and you'll boost your ability to resist temptation
items.description: Losing your gut is as much about strength of mind as it is about diet and working out. Train your self-control like a muscle and you'll boost your ability to resist temptation
items.title: How to boost your willpower
items.meta_title: Losing your gut is as much about strength of mind as it is about diet and working out. Train your self-control like a muscle and you'll boost your ability to resist temptation
items.body:
One glazed doughnut sits on a desk directly in your line of sight. You, in pursuit of a leaner physique, resolve not to eat it. The doughnut doesn’t budge and nor do you; it’s a sprinkle-topped Mexican stand-off loaded with jam and 300 calories. Whether you win or lose the battle is a simple matter of willpower.

Now, before you give in to the jam-splattered conclusion, know this: willpower can be trained. Just like a bicep, your resolve gets fatigued as you use it and gets stronger if you exercise it properly. Research into self-control shows that if you exercise discipline to meet one goal, you will be mentally fitter to take on the next.

Warm up your willpower
Take a small goal that you can train in a specific situation. For example, every time you pick up Men's Health, read it whilst holding a good seated posture. This has nothing to do with weight loss but, over time, it builds up your mental reserve of willpower.

Halfway through a gruelling summer diet, exercise and detox regime, most people could use that extra self-will. “One of the biggest mistakes people make is that they pursue more than one goal simultaneously,” says John Tierney, co-author of Willpower: Rediscovering Our Greatest Strength. “We try to lose weight at the same time as quitting cigarettes. But these things draw on the same limited resource of willpower in your body.”

Pick one goal
Cut out alcohol, or reduce your carb intake, or stop swearing. Attempt them all and you're unlikely to achieve any.

Success tastes sweet

Willpower is not hard-wired into your personality. In fact, it ebbs and flows thanks to glucose. Your body converts food into this simple sugar and your brain uses it when you concentrate and make choices. When glucose levels are low, you’re more likely to give in to temptation. And it’s not just doughnuts, but vices of all kinds: cigarettes, sex, the internet, yawning in a meeting, rolling your eyes at your wife. Anything you have to fight the urge to do.

One of the main reasons shedding a stone or two is difficult is that the willpower to achieve long-term goals shares the same store of glucose as smaller, everyday goals.

Lose weight right now
"I will cut out 250 calories today" works better than "I'll lose 10lb by April". Make your goals immediate, specific and achievable, and the end results will happen.

Research by Dr Roy Baumeister, a psychologist at Florida State University and Willpower’s co-author, found that people actively resist temptation for three to four hours every day. “When willpower is low, people abandon long-term goals and operate on a short-term focus,” Baumeister says.

Even simple decision-making drains your willpower. If you make lots of little choices ahead of meal-time – comparing calories or deciding where to eat – you suffer from 'decision fatigue', leaving you weaker in the face of temptation two hours later. Your willpower muscle gets overworked and tired, leaving nothing in the tank to fight the next lure.

Have a to-don't list ready
Decide ahead of time what you're not going to do in specific scenarios, such as "I am not going to have mini pizzas at the buffet." It pre-programs your willpower for tempting situations.

items.teaser: Get style and substance with our guide to ensure you dress for success at every stage of your career
items.sub_heading: Today’s high-flyer needs style as well as substance to reach the very top of his game. MH shows you how to look the business at every stage of your career
items.description: Today’s high-flyer needs style as well as substance to reach the very top of his game. MH shows you how to dress for success at every stage of your career
items.title: Dress for career success
items.meta_title: MH shows you how to dress for success at every stage of your career
items.body:
If you subscribe to the Warren Buffett school of wealth accumulation – and why wouldn’t you, he’s the third richest man in the world – you’ll agree that financial success is fundamentally about getting the most value from your assets. In today’s economic landscape making the right impression will help you get ahead of the competition. So when it comes to that job interview, first day or pay review, you need to make sure you look the part in order to get the part you want.

You’re never buying ‘just another suit’. Your everyday business uniform could be the difference between sealing that big deal, scoring a pay rise, or securing your dream job. Lest there’s any doubt: the psychological and financial advantages to be accrued by dressing well are not to be scoffed at.

Oscar Udeshi, a former City man turned menswear designer, has an insider’s insight into the importance of image in business. “If your appearance doesn’t send out the right message, there can be a lack of trust,” he says. Your look has to communicate that you are trustworthy, responsible, sincere and likeable, particularly at an interview.

And your first day in a new job presents another conundrum: how will you look impressive while still fitting in? “You don’t want to go over the top, but you don’t want to be mistaken for the post boy either,” says Udeshi. So turn up looking smart, but safely outside the realms of sartorial excess.

Once you’ve put your stamp on the company, it’s time to ask for a pay rise. Looking the part puts you on the front foot. A study published in the Journal of Personality and Social Psychology found attractive communicators were more persuasive than average looking ones – so the better you look, the better your chances of getting the rise you’re after.

An economic downturn can be fortuitous for some: a reduced workforce leaves greater scope for good people to rise faster. At this stage, you’d do well to concentrate on the details of your outfit, to set you apart from your colleagues and other candidates – and we’ll show you exactly what to focus on.

And having been granted the corner office, your PA and company equity, finally getting a seat on the board is not an excuse to let your image slip. Your look needs to be inspirational without being pompous – business is hardly booming, remember? So quality of fabrics and materials is key.

Whatever level you’re at, underestimate the importance of your image at your peril. The wrong outfit can short-sell your talent, but the right one can leverage your potential many times over. Allow MH to show you how to do it in fine style.

items.teaser: Hormones, drugs, even pesticides could be flowing from your faucet. No one can say for sure, because the government doesn't require testing for them. But in groundbreaking research, Good Housekeeping found five ordinary water pitchers and refrigerator filters that can get rid of these scary chemicals
items.sub_heading: Hormones, drugs, even pesticides could be flowing from your faucet. No one can say for sure, because the government doesn't require testing for them. But in groundbreaking research, Good Housekeeping found ordinary water pitchers and refrigerator filters that can get rid of these scary chemicals
items.description: Hormones, drugs, even pesticides could be flowing from your faucet. No one can say for sure, because the government doesn't require testing for them.
items.title: Is Your Tap Water Safe?
items.meta_title: Safe Tap Water - Safe Drinking Water
items.body:
It's mid-afternoon, and I'm at my desk writing, eating leftover pasta, and sipping a glass of water. I hear the mailbox creak open outside and hop up to retrieve its contents. Bills. More bills. And my yearly water report. I pop open the circle of plastic tape and read the results: no violations. My water is in compliance with every drinking-water standard regulated by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). Not that it's perfect: Barium, chromium, copper, lead, nitrate, and other chemicals, as well as E. coli (E. coli!?), have been detected over the past year.

In fact, those contaminants are proverbial drops in the bucket. Antibiotics, hormones, a cancer drug, a chemical found in gasoline, antiseizure medication...research shows that hundreds of unregulated contaminants may be flowing from my tap — largely invisible, tasteless, and undetectable. They won't be on my water report (or yours) because they are not on the government's list of contaminants to monitor. And although they're at low levels, no one knows how dangerous they might be when they're all mixed together in the water supply and consumed over a lifetime. The government has frequently been criticized for being too lax about chemicals, but last August, the nonpartisan Government Accountability Office issued a report urging the EPA to coordinate research on what contaminants like these could be doing to us.

That's why, to help you take matters into your own hands, Good Housekeeping partnered with the Arizona Laboratory for Emerging Contaminants at the University of Arizona, one of the world's leading labs for study of unregulated chemicals. Together with the GH Research Institute, the lab performed extensive testing — the first-ever such analysis — to see whether everyday filters, like the ones in water pitchers and refrigerators, can remove some of these chemicals. GH also joined forces with the Water Sciences Laboratory at the University of Nebraska in order to test home contaminant-detection kits.

Here's what you need to know, plus smart, easy ways to protect your family.


What's (Sort of) Regulated

By law, your local water system must test municipal drinking water for some 90 substances and organisms — including copper, uranium, and lead — and report whether any have been found and at what levels, as well as whether any exceed federally mandated Maximum Contaminant Levels — MCLs (For information on how to read your water report, pick up a copy of the March 2012 issue of Good Housekeeping). And if the levels are too high? Then, under the federal Safe Drinking Water Act and Amendments, your town is supposed to take measures to lower them.

Yet in fiscal year 2010 (the latest data available), 10% of all community water systems — serving more than 23 million people — sold water to consumers that violated at least one health-based EPA standard. Many of those violations were due to elevated levels of coliform bacteria, an indicator of how well a treatment plant is (or isn't) cleaning the water. When coliform levels are high, it can mean the water isn't being adequately disinfected — and other bacteria, such as E. coli, could well be thriving, too. The treatment plant must then do further testing for the more dangerous bacteria, including those that cause GI illnesses (diarrhea, vomiting), which can be particularly risky for small children and the elderly.


Next: The violations we know about, and the ones we don't

items.teaser: A warming stew full of bright, crisp veggies, lean chicken, and spicy andouille sausage, this gumbo is a stick-to-your-ribs dish that's perfect during the cold winter months.
items.description: A warming stew full of bright, crisp veggies, lean chicken, and spicy andouille sausage, this gumbo is a stick-to-your-ribs dish that's perfect during the cold winter months.
items.title: Chicken-and-Andouille Gumbo
items.meta_title: Chicken and Andouille Gumbo Recipe

ingredient.ingredient_old: 2½ pounds chicken (2 skinless thighs; 2 large boneless, skinless breast halves)
ingredient.ingredient_name: chicken (2 skinless thighs; 2 large boneless, skinless breast halves)

ingredient.ingredient_old: 1 tablespoon Creole seasoning (such as Tony Chachere’s)
4 large bell peppers (2 red, 2 green), diced
½ cup fresh chopped parsley, for garnish

preparation_step.preparation_step: Sprinkle chicken with salt and let sit for 10 minutes. Meanwhile, in a large resealable plastic bag, combine 1/4 cup flour, Creole seasoning, and garlic powder. In a large Dutch oven over medium-high heat, heat 2 tablespoons oil. Add chicken to bag, 1 piece at a time, and shake to coat. Transfer chicken to pot and cook over medium heat, turning once, until golden brown, about 5 minutes per side.

Transfer chicken to a paper-towel-lined plate and add sausage to pot. Cook until lightly browned, about 3 minutes. Add peppers and onion, and cook until slightly softened, 5 to 7 minutes. Transfer sausage-vegetable mixture to a bowl and set aside.

Wipe pot clean and set on medium-low heat. Add remaining flour and oil, and stir constantly until a deep-brown roux forms, about 10 minutes. Add reserved sausage-vegetable mixture and stir to combine. Stir in chicken broth, increase heat to medium-high, and bring to a boil. Add chicken, reduce heat to medium-low, and allow to simmer for about 40 minutes.

Remove chicken from pot and shred into bite-size pieces, discarding thigh bones. Return chicken to pot and add tomatoes and okra. Simmer until okra is tender, about 10 minutes. Serve over rice. Garnish with parsley.

body.intro_text: A warming stew full of bright, crisp veggies, lean chicken, and spicy andouille sausage, this gumbo is a stick-to-your-ribs dish that's perfect during the cold winter months.

preparation_step.preparation_step: Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil over high heat. Meanwhile, in a large skillet over medium heat, heat oil and pepper. Add escarole and sauté until it wilts, about 4 minutes, stirring occasionally. Add wine and 1 cup water, partially cover pot, and let escarole cook for about 6 minutes.
Cook pasta in boiling water for 6 minutes. Drain pasta and add to escarole. Toss; top with Parmesan and parsley. Serve hot.

items.teaser: We all do. Don’t we? MH investigates the science and ethics of immortality
items.sub_heading: We all do. Don’t we? With scientists now claiming immortality is a possibility within your lifetime, MH asks the big question: would you really want to live forever?
items.description: We all do. Don’t we? With scientists now claiming immortality is a possibility within your lifetime, MH asks the big question: would you really want to?
items.title: Who wants to live forever?
items.meta_title: We ask the big question: would you really want to live forever?
items.body:
For some people, it’s easy to dismiss the concept of immortality as fantasy. Or to believe that, even if it were a possibility, they wouldn’t want it. Call it arrogance. Or anxiety, maybe.

Recent biomedical advancements in the research spheres of stem cells, molecular repair, cloning, synthetic organs and cybernetics are already improving people’s life expectancy. Now scientists are daring to believe those developments could soon stop ageing decisively. Life extension. The end of death, bar fatal trauma.

The initial therapies are the hard bit: tissue engineering (creating organs in a lab and transplanting them), stem cell therapy (injecting ‘repair’ cells into the patient) and molecular regenerative medicine (repairing cells within the body). Current thinking is that there’s a 50% chance of getting it all done within 25 years.

Those therapies would be applied to middle-aged people, whose bodies haven’t suffered any serious damage. It would grant another 30 years of healthy life. Then when the patient comes back after 30 years the new therapies would have improved. The patient would be rejuvenated for longer. Therapies would improve again. The patient would not age. In the business of beating death, this is known as ‘longevity escape velocity’.

Even if you don’t escape and fatal trauma shuts the gate before we’ve all bolted, it’s not the end. You can come back. In the past two years, improved availability of cryonic techniques have sparked a price-war between clinics all over the world. From those in the US offering eternal-life insurance for $30 (£20) a month, all the way to a centre outside Moscow where they’ll preserve your head for as little as £6,000, coming back from the beyond is suddenly far less far-fetched. However much or little you pay, the promise is the same – suspension of your being until a time when death isn’t death any more.

We’re used to death, though. It’s ‘just a part of life’. Death has a psychological stranglehold over us; we’ve convinced ourselves it’s good because we think we can’t do anything about it. We’re afraid of immortality because it’s unfamiliar. We come up with ‘crazy’ reasons why it would be bad. We say we’d be bored; there’d be too many of us; dictators would terrorise forever. We want death instead.

But immortality is too important to sweep under the exisistential carpet. After all, billions of lives are at stake. Your life is at stake. Mine is too. For me – stocky, a history of early strokes in the family, atheist – death is increasingly real and terrifying. The scientists are claiming that it needn’t be the former; the philosophers say the latter shouldn’t worry you. Who should you believe? If the scientists are right, why don’t we embrace them as the saviours of a world’s worth of existences? Are we more scared of their eternal life than our own death? It’s immortalists vs deathists. Whose side are you on?

Life as we know it

Imagine if it worked. Life becomes a cruise instead of a race. No panic over ageing (300 is the new 30) and no need to stress with an eternity of tomorrows. It would be glorious, but we don’t want it.

To find out why, I decided to start as close to my home in the North East of England as possible: Ian Ground, senior philosophy lecturer at Sunderland University’s Centre for Lifelong Learning. We sit down in his office. He says he just gave a lecture on immortality and the arguments are fresh in his mind. Perfect. He says the world would become a worse place. The population would rise dramatically and basic resources would be scarce. Inequalities would increase. Dictators would live indefinitely (the Church of England’s medical ethics advisor also uses the same argument, saying mortality is good because it limits “the amount of evil” a person can do). And, of course, we’d be old.

“Typically people get more conservative as they get older,” says Ground. “They could become resistant to change, so what’s going to happen to innovation? There are questions about society stagnating. Most of us wouldn’t want the world to be run by our grandfathers.”

Then come problems for the individual. Things don’t get any perkier.

“Scientists think we can go on discovering things about the universe forever,” he continues. “Maybe we can, but what we aren’t envisaging is just becoming knowledge-acquiring machines for the rest of our lives. We need feelings and relationships, not just work.

“We’re used to the idea of birth, growth and development, a period of maturity, gradual tailing off, and hopefully a dignified retirement and death. We don’t know what happens if we plateau. We have no idea whether the human mind can survive that. It may be that we just get profoundly bored.”



Never-ending story

Boredom is a frequent fear with deathists. But would you get bored? Surely life would become infinitely more interesting? Every decade you could have a gap year.

You’d have a list of ex-girlfriends like the Domesday Book. And if it got that bad, you could just throw in the towel. But journalist Bryan Appleyard, author of How to Live Forever or Die Trying, says ennui would set in.

“Some gerontologists say ‘If you’re bored why don’t you learn quantum mechanics or learn to speak Arabic?’” he tells me. “Well I don’t want to learn Arabic. Just because I’m 200 years old won’t make me more keen on doing those things.

“I think there’s a point that the immortalists don’t understand, and it’s that one exhausts one’s own personality over a certain period. It’s a weird idea that you would go on and on, still being interested in being yourself. I don’t think anyone would. I think you’d get excruciatingly bored of being yourself.”

If you want to know what living forever would be like, you talk to gerontologist Aubrey De Grey. He was the subject of a previous MH profile, detailing his first acts as the frontman of immortalism. Since then, De Grey has continued on in his self-propelled race towards reaching the ‘longevity escape velocity’.

He suggests we meet over a beer but our schedules clash, so we arrange to speak on the phone. From internet videos I know he looks like a slacker Druid: long beard, jeans, trainers and crystal eyes.

De Grey has an answer for Appleyard: “Wouldn’t it be boring? Wouldn’t dictators live forever? I’m not saying the reasons they give are stupid. I’m just saying it’s unbelievably absurd to raise them as objections to solving a rather major problem that we have today, namely the ill-health of old age.

“I don’t want to be the sort of person who condemns humanity to an unnecessarily early death, just because I thought I knew what life would be like in the future.”

De Grey has a phenomenal brain. He studied computing science at Cambridge University and taught himself the science of ageing. Now he’s researching regenerative medicines. He believes he will discover biological immortality before the white coats of the traditional scientific establishment. People believe him, enough to fund his laboratory in California.

He tells me about the laboratory; about the mice; the cells and molecules; the rich backers (including Peter Thiel, co-founder of PayPal). He talks about his belief that someone alive today may live to be 1,000. You can laugh, but he’s cleverer than you are.

The disposable body

“Aubrey is a... very skilled showman.” Tom Kirkwood runs the Institute for Ageing and Health in the western suburbs of Newcastle upon Tyne – the biggest facility of its kind in Europe. Outside it’s leafy and peaceful. Inside it’s hard science. It’s a pretty far cry from De Grey’s sunny California base.

Kirkwood is the dean of ageing. In 2001 he gave the Reith Lectures – a renowned BBC radio series assessing the most vital contemporary issues of our time. In his lectures Kirkwood described how our (humanity’s) life expectancy doubled over the past two centuries. We (scientists) did it mainly by defeating acute infectious diseases. Now ageing is our bête noire, bringing with it cancer, stroke and heart disease. If you live long enough, your chances of being struck down with any, or even all, of the above increase exponentially. Kirkwood teaches me about ageing as we drink tea.

We are not programmed to age, he says. It’s just a build-up of damage. Kirkwood published a famous theory around this: our bodies are able to repair themselves and avoid ageing, but they divert the energy towards reproduction. Historically we were likely to be eaten by badgers or crushed by a menhir long before ageing became relevant. Repair was pointless.

He calls this the ‘disposable soma’ theory. It was published in 1977, after he thought of it while having a bath (take note all those who hurry in the shower). Now he’s spending his life learning how to stop the damage of ageing. It’s a growing field and a complicated field. It’s noteworthy that cancer gets a lot more investment and we (again, the scientists) haven’t fixed that yet. Kirkwood is a lot less optimistic than De Grey.

“What Aubrey has done,” he says, “is to look at this from an engineering perspective. He’s got a list of things he feels need to be fixed and he says, ‘Right, we’ll fix them and we’ll all live for a thousand years.’

“Well, in principle, who can argue with that? The reason I criticise him really very strongly, is he grossly distorts the scale of the scientific challenge and raises completely false expectations about what is likely to happen. And people get excited by it. I think that’s wrong.”

Kirkwood is one of 28 genterologists who co-authored a paper critical of this approach in 2005. It claimed De Grey was in the “realm of fantasy”. They said ageing research is only just emerging from a reputation of quackery and beginning to be taken seriously. Put simply, they don’t want De Grey’s “empty fantasies” cocking things up.

De Grey’s retort was to quote Lord Kelvin from 1895: “Heavier-than-air flying machines are impossible”. He went on to say that life extension is a form of engineering and its goals, methods and skills are different to those of science. He ended by saying, “lives, lots of them, are at stake”. Kirkwood still hasn’t been persuaded.

“I work in mainstream biomedical research,” he says, “and these kinds of arguments discourage mainstream science from taking ageing as seriously as it needs to be taken. It’s damaging to the interests of older people, so I feel very strongly that what he is doing is wrong.”

De Grey stands by his predictions. Kirkwood by his proof. But if immortality is just around the corner, who would want to miss it when it does come around? Stick it out long enough, and you could decide whether living forever is what you want with all the facts of immortality in front of you. There is already a way you can.

Frozen in time

In 1948, an American wrier named Robert Ettinger wrote a short story for a magazine. It was about a man who was revived after centuries of being frozen. In 1964 he wrote a book called The Prospect of Immortality. It's about freezing real people in the hope that future science will resurrect them. He writes about repair and rejuvenation, transplants and prostheses, organ culture and regeneration (De Grey is a great admirer). Three years after publishing the book, a retired psychology professor became the first cryonics patient. In 1976 Ettinger opened the Cryonics Institute in Michigan.

When Ettinger died, aged 92, he became the 106th person to be frozen at the institute. Currently there are about 200 people frozen in various cryonics facilities around the world, mostly in America. De Grey is registered to be frozen at Alcor in Arizona. Adherents believe cold storage is preferable to the grave. It gives them hope of a wonderful afterlife: the future.

I call Dr Brendan McCarthy, the medical ethics advisor for the Church of England, to ask if he has any objections to this ‘afterlife’. Would he want it? He says Christians have a better offer: life with God. I ask if he understands why some of us want immortality.

“I think some people believe that when their body stops functioning as a physical organism that’s it, that’s simply the end,” he says. “They have a desire to keep on living and do better things, but they believe there is nothing. And they fear that.”

Your second coming

In the end, the entire subject of immortality is one of fear. We’re scared both of terminal death and of endless life. Professor Nick Zangwill, a philosopher at Durham University, has the final word on why some of us are now increasingly desperate to live on. He’s working late and scribbles some thoughts down on an email. What he says strikes to the very heart of the eternal question: “One might feel disappointed with the life one’s led, but clinging on to more isn’t necessarily going to right that. I suppose one might have a chance to live the life one would like to have lived. But what you’re really wanting is to live your life again but better. And that’s impossible.”

The 101st patient at the Cryonics Institute was an 18-year-old boy. He suffered from depression and committed suicide in late 2010. After he died his parents signed him up for freezing. His body was packed in dried ice, put on a plane and taken to Michigan. Upon arrival he was stored in a cryostat, an 18-year-old-boy-sized thermos bottle full of liquid nitrogen.

You can see why his parents did it. If you think immortality is impossible it’s easy to dismiss. But if you believe? That’s when you want it. That’s when you hope. In a world where the logic of science is more quantifiable, more acceptable to our mindset than the promises of religion, hope is the new afterlife. The boy’s parents hoped badly. They wanted him to have another chance, even if he didn’t. They wanted another chance. Whether you believe an end to death is something you truly want or not, it’s the same reason any of us want immortality: please, one more chance. Just give me more time.


Illustrations: Noma Bar; Words: Andrew Hankinson

Follow MH on Twitter and Facebook

items.teaser: Celebs making Twits of themselves in the social sphere
items.sub_heading: Oops! Former NDubz stars (and cousins) Dappy and Tulisa took to Twitter last night for an intense argument - it seems as if Tulisa HATES Dappy's latest video! Celebrities sometimes make the biggest Twitter mistakes! Tulisa and Dappy aren't the only ones; from Kim Kardashian, Rihanna to Charlie Sheen – here's a list of celebs who've made the ultimate Twitter blunders…
items.description: Oops! Celebrities sometimes make the biggest mistakes on Twitter - see more at cosmopolitan.co.uk
items.title: Top 10 celebrity Twitter blunders
items.meta_title: Top ten celebrity Twitter blunders
items.body:
1.Tulisa and Dappy
Former NDubz bandmates (and cousins) Dappy and Tulisa hit the headlines last night, after a family spat got out of control on the social netowrking site. When Tulisa made a jibe about Dappy's new music video - she officially hates it - Dappy got a little upset...

"Now why would u say that,,,i cant believe u T...Why would u say this about my work..Just so u can keep cool with your xf job"

Oh Dappy. Dappy, Dappy, DAPPY! Never mention The X Factor. The comment about Tulisa's job clearly hit a nerve and the talent judge completely lost it, telling him that, one day, she would get him back into shape:

"@thedappy stop cussin peeps out 4 ratins! talent speaks 4 itself u little sh*t.Wen will u bloody learn!wen we unite Im gettin u back in shape... ur a talented little f*cker with to many issues!sort it out daps friggin sort it out!!!"

That would have been OUR cue to button that lip - Tulisa can be pretty feisty when she's angry, after all. But, judging from Dappy's latest tweet, this feud is FAR from over...

"Like i told u im just warming up..Its only right 1 of us tells it how it should be..#YgetFameThenChange"

Yikes! We guess the pair didn't learn that airing your private battles in the Twittersphere is a pretty embarrassing idea when it comes to the morning after...

2. Diane Abbott
When young writer Bim Adewunmi expressed her concern for the term 'black community' being used too loosely, we're sure she didn't expect to receive a tweet reply from MP Diane Abbott. Unfortunately for Ms. Abbott, her tweet  that 'white people love playing divide and rule' caused uproar, which lead to her being ordered to apologise by her boss Labour leader Ed Milliband. Diane later said the tweet was taken out of context - whoops, better book yourself in for more media (and Twitter) training in the future, Diane…

3. Jessica Wright
TOWIE star Jessica Wright found herself trending on Twitter in December 2011 - for all the wrong reasons. When North Korean dictator Kim Jong-il died, Jessica gave her deep-felt condolences by tweeting 'Rest in peace.' We're pretty sure she didn't expect the backlash she was to receive - Kim Jong-il didn't go down as the most pleasant man in history, and poor Jessica clearly didn't do her research before tweeting – oops!

4. Kim Kardashian
When Kim took a quick Twitter photo of herself holding a cat by the scruff of its neck, she received tons of complaints. Many Twitter users were worried about the way Kim had held the cat, but she later said the cat's owner was present and she would never harm any animals. Phew! Be careful Kim, you don't want to get in any more trouble with animal protesters

5. Ashton Kutcher
2011 was a testing year for Ashton Kutcher. If the separation between him and his wife Demi Moore wasn't challenging enough, it appears managing his twitter account also proved to be difficult. Ashton received backlash after tweeting messages of support to football coach Joe Paterno, who had been accused of failing to act after being made aware of child abuse. As a result, Ashton Kutcher said he was letting his management take over his Twitter account. Erm, now that he's no longer tweeting sickly cute photos of him and Demi we think that sounds like a pretty good idea…

6. Russell Brand
Russell Brand made the awful mistake of tweeting a photo of his ex-wife Katy Perry - with no makeup on. Yikes! He said it was an innocent mistake and that he never intended to publish to his Twitter account - followed by millions. Was this the real reason why the marriage failed?

7. Piers Morgan
Remember the famous gagging order that prevented anyone from saying which 'high profile footballer' was having an affair? Well Piers Morgan ignored that rule, and revealed the man in question was Ryan Giggs. Oops! But we all knew anyway, didn't we?

8. Charlie Sheen
Charlie Sheen made the ultimate Twitter mistake of direct messaging his mobile number to Justin Bieber - only for it to end up on his timeline. It was no surprise that Charlie's phone was ringing off the hook for days afterwards…

9. Chris Brown
When Chris Brown picked up a Grammy this year, following his three year ban after his assault on ex-girlfriend Rihanna, not everyone was all too happy about it. Rather than sit back and let the critics run their course, Chris Brown decided to respond in the only way he knew how: "HATE ALL YOU WANT BECUZ I GOT A GRAMMY Now! That's the ultimate F**K OFF!" Unsurprisingly, the public and press didn't respond too well to that little outburst...

10. Rihanna
Rihanna is known for spending an awful lot of her free time of Twitter, and even sends occasional tweets to ex-boyfriend Chris Brown. But she may have gone a tweet too far when she wrote cryptic messages soon after Chris Brown posted a pic of him and his new girlfriend - suggesting a certain someone is lying to their girlfriend while laying with her. Oh no she didn't? Oh yes, she did!

items.description: Seven effort-free ways to blag yourself midriff muscle
items.title: Your six-pack cheat sheet
items.meta_title: Seven effort-free ways to blag yourself midriff muscle
items.body:
Sleep on it

Your bed is a weight–loss tool. No, not like that, Casanova. We're talking about sleep. Those who get four hours kip eat 263 more calories each day than those who sleep for the recommended eight. Lack of Zzzs spikes your hunger hormones, found a study by New York's Obesity Nutrition Research Centre.

Get milk

To specifically target belly fat, eat a high-protein, low–carb and calorie–light diet in which the majority of your proteins come from dairy, says the Journal of Nutrition. "Increasing calcium and protein in your diet encourages fat loss from the worst storage area in your body – your belly," says study author Andrea Josse.

Get fresh

Pollution could be giving you a gut. Researchers at Ohio State University found exposure to dirty air leads to more abdominal fat than breathing fresh air. Pollutants may trigger an increase in fat cells, say the scientists, so wear a cycling mask when commuting in the city.

Block out burns

If you drink a strong coffee before training, you'll be able to work harder and longer, found scientists at the University of Louisiana. "Caffeine blocks some of the pain receptors in your muscles," says lead researcher Dr David Bellar. He suggests that caffeine is most effective when drunk 45 minutes before you hit the weights. Gingerbread latte is unlikely to have the same effects, however.

Flex your imagination

When the going gets tough, think of a previous sporting victory. In a new British study, men who recalled a previously energising activity while cycling had more fun and felt more revitalised than those who didn’t. "Imagining an action rouses the same areas of the brain as performing it," says study author Dr Damian Stanley.

Build tension

In the world of abs, resistance is not futile. In fact, it's essential. "When doing abs exercises where you raise your legs, such as hanging leg raises, make sure you don't let your legs return to 180 degrees," says strength coach Mark Coles. "This keeps the tension on them, working your abs."

Choose wisely

Protein shakes can help you burn fat as well as build muscle. A new Swiss study found that casein is better than whey because you digest it slower. If you prefer whey, mix it with milk (80% of milk’s protein is casein).

Get constantly evolving workout and nutrition plans personalised for your specific needs and training goals. Sign up to Men's Health's Personal Trainer tool now!

items.sub_heading: Beat lousy interest rates by doing the investing yourself. Use these tips from Clem Chambers, author of 101 Ways to Pick Stock Market Winners to find out where the smart money goes
items.description: Beat lousy interest rates by doing the investing yourself. Use these tips from Clem Chambers, author of 101 Ways to Pick Stock Market Winners to find out where the smart money goes
items.title: How to pick a stock market winner
items.meta_title: Beat lousy interest rates by doing the investing yourself
items.body:
Buy low P/E stock

This is how Warren Buffett made his money. The P/E number is the ratio of share price to company earnings – the lower the number, the more cash the company is making.

Follow the directors

When a company’s directors buy, you buy too. Find out when they’re investing on advfn.com. (NB If they're jumping out of windows, don’t follow.)

Buy after the market crashes

But only when papers like The Sun say the world's ending. The red tops lag behind the market, so when they say it's nearly bottomed out, it is time to buy.

Beware the summer slump

It's the only predictable market trend: lazy hedge fund managers going on long holidays from May. So wait until September.

Buy companies that rise a little every day

It's a sign that smart people are buying into them long-term. Remember that this depression is an economic one, not a market one, so there are still great opportunities to make money if you follow the right rules.

items.promo_teaser: Get back into training quicker after injury with our guide to this common shoulder injury
items.keywords: sports training, shoulder tendonitis, prevent injury
items.teaser: Get back into training quicker after injury with our guide to this common shoulder injury
items.sub_heading: Get back into training quicker after injury with our guide to this common shoulder injury
items.description: Get back into training quicker after injury with our guide to this common shoulder injury
items.title: Injury clinic: Shoulder tendonitis
items.meta_title: Get back into training quicker after injury with our guide to this common shoulder injury
items.body:
Danger sports Swimming, surfing, cricket and all sports that involve throwing

What it is

The shoulder joint is stabilised by the rotator cuff, which is made up of four muscles: the supraspinatus, infraspinatus, subscapularis and teres minor. These form a 'cuff' around the ball of the shoulder joint to prevent too much joint movement. Tendonitis (also known as rotator cuff tendonitis or impingement syndrome) is when the tendons of these muscles are overused and inflamed.

How you damage it

The most common causes are bad movement techniques and poor form when lifting weights; overuse of the shoulder joint; or muscular imbalances in one of the four muscles. This happens a lot in sports where the shoulder is lifted overhead repeatedly. Many muscular forces work around the shoulder, so tendonitis occurs if any are unbalanced in strength or length.

Symptoms

A sharp pain at the top of the shoulder when you lift your arm overhead during sport, or a dull ache behind your shoulder after sport. You may hear a pop or click. In chronic cases the rotator cuff can tear, necessitating surgery.

Fix it

Use the RICE method (rest, ice, compression, elevation) and an anti-inflammatory gel (such as Pernaton) over the affected area for the first 48 hours.

Shoulder tendonitis tends to re-occur so if it won't respond to RICE and continues for more than two weeks, see a physio for stabilisation exercises and specialist care. If you were hit on the arm and can't lift it more than 90 degrees, you may have a rotator-cuff tear. Seek immediate help from your doctor or local A&E.

How long you’ll be out

If properly treated, you shouldn't be crocked for more than 14 days. In mild cases, with proper care, you might not have to stop sport at all, but simply change your training techniques or reduce the time spent playing. The rule is, if the pain is so bad you have to stop playing then rest until it heals. But if you only feel pain after sport, use RICE after each session, stretch and see a physio.

Prevent it

Stretch your lats and chest during warm-ups and cool-downs. In the gym, work on shoulder stabilisers, such as your traps, and during all upper-body training, keep your shoulders back and down during reps to build shoulder stability. If you swim or surf, remember to stretch your lats, especially during cool-downs.


Words: Mike Squirrell

Follow MH on Twitter and Facebook

items.teaser: Invest in the essential kit you need to excavate your abs – no gym required!
items.sub_heading: Invest in the essential kit you need to excavate your abs – no gym required!
items.description: Invest in the essential kit you'll need to excavate your six pack – no gym required!
items.title: The ultimate six-pack-sculpting gear
items.meta_title: Invest in the essential kit you'll need to excavate your six pack – no gym required!
items.body:
1. Set the bar

Turn your door frame into a multi-gym. Pull-up bars are great for performing stabilising moves. Hold the bar in either an over- or under-hand grip, let your body hang, then raise your knees and tuck them to your chest. Tense your stomach, and don't let go.
York Doorway Chinning Bar, £16, dolphinfitness.co.uk

2. Get on track

Your cheapest tool for stripping away that flabby exterior is the great outdoors. To get more from your run, wear split-toe shoes, which allow greater traction from your big toe. You'll run further and longer, torching even more fat.
Brooks PureCadence, £100, brooksrunning.co.uk

3. Take your medicine

Med balls can be thrown, twisted, lifted and lowered to add weight to your standard routine. Try this: in a sit-up position, hold the ball in front of you. Twist your trunk to the left, then the right. Repeat for solid obliques.
66Fit Double-Handle Medicine Ball, £41, amazon.co.uk

4. Dial it up

These smart dumbbells deliver a range of weights from 2-32.5kg at the twist of a dial, so you can tweak the weight in stages. Perform a squat holding the dumbbell at chest height and then explode upwards, pressing the dumbbell above you.
York Dial Tech Dumbbells and Stand, £340, amazon.co.uk

5. Get in the swing of it

All PTs champion the kettlebells for their core-sculpting ability. Perform a kettlebell swing: keep your back straight, hold it between your legs, then swing your hips (controlling with your abs) until it reaches eye level.
Bodymax Vinyl Kettlebell, £21, powerhouse-fitness.co.uk

6. Hang tough

Created by a taekwondo champion, the TRX trainer forces you to use your core strength to stabilise during every move. Attach one end to a sturdy support and perform four sets of 15 over-the-shoulder chops. Then have a lie-down.
TRX Rip Trainer, £150, trxfitness.co.uk

items.promo_teaser: The deadlift is the most basic of all strength-builders but is often done incorrectly. Here's how to do it
items.keywords: deadlift, muscle exercise, perfect form, how to do

related_links_list.link_text: How to create the perfect quiff

items.teaser: The deadlift is the most basic of all strength-builders but is often done incorrectly. Here's how to do it
items.sub_heading: The deadlift is the most basic of all strength-builders but is one that's often done incorrectly. Here's how it should be done
items.description: The deadlift is the most basic of all strength-builders but is one that's often done incorrectly. Here's how it should be done
items.title: Perfect your form: the deadlift
items.meta_title: The deadlift is the most basic of all strength-builders but is often done incorrectly. Here's how to do it

blog_element.paragraph:
How to do it

Load the barbell and roll it up to your shins. Straighten your legs a bit (to take up the slack as you want tension on the bar at the start), squeeze your glutes, tighten your shoulder blades and pull in your lower abs. Then straighten your legs by imagining you're pushing your feet through the floor.

Continue a smooth movement as you stand up, straightening the rest of your body using the driving force of your glutes. Finish in an upright position with your shoulders back and down and your lower back still flat. Throughout this whole move, the bar should stay in contact with your skin.

For the lowering stage, slide the bar down your thigh and shins to the floor. This stage isn't necessarily the exact reverse of the raising stage as your purpose is simply to the get the bar back on the floor safely.

Perfect form

Your back It's vital to maintain a straight back throughout the entire movement. Do this by forcing your gluteals out and tensing them. Your glutes and thighs will carry the highest workload, so concentrate on working them.

Your feet Keep your feet shoulder-width apart, pressing down on the floor to provide a stable platform from which your glutes can work as prime movers.

Your trunk and hips These should remain at or near the same angle. This is critical as getting this wrong causes more injuries than any other technical error in this exercise.

Your neck Keep a still, slightly upward-facing neck throughout the movement. Thrusting your chin forward will help. Fix your vision on a point and keep your head facing forward.

Your shoulders Squeeze your shoulder blades together. This will pull your shoulders back, promoting strength in your trapezius muscles – needed to maintain a straight neck. If you're hunched forward, adjust your form – the weight must NOT hang from your arms.

Your grip Hold the bar firmly with an overhand grip, shoulder-width apart. Keep your hands just outside your knees, tensing your wrists throughout the movement.
